But Bates wasn't holding a Taser. He was holding his gun. He fired one shot and killed Harris. From a policing perspective, there wasn't even good reason to use a Taser against Harris. Cops were on scene. Harris wasn't getting the upper hand. He wasn't going anywhere. And despite what Bates would later claim, Harris was not running like a man with a gun. In fact, Harris was running fast and his arms were pumping very much like a man who is not protecting a gun in his waistband. What was Bates, an insurance company CEO, doing there in the first place? It certainly looks like Bates was given special access to "real" policing. Harris had given $2,500 to Sheriff Stanley Glanz's re-election campaign. He donated cars to the department. He gave equipment. So it would be noteworthy if Bates ends up being convicted based on evidence provided by "sunglass cameras" that he may have purchased for the department. A Tulsa police official said the agency has 130 reserve deputies, many of them wealthy people who make donations to the police. "That's not unusual at all," he told the Tulsa World. Maybe Bates could have been a reserve deputy without donating anything. But I doubt there are many volunteer septuagenarians working with the violent crimes task force. He was too old to be policing the streets. Tulsa police said that Bates had served a year in 1964 as a police officer. Most police departments have mandatory retirement ages. Federal law-enforcement officers, for instance, retire at 57. How easy is it to confuse a gun for a Taser? Police officers generally look with a skeptical eye toward volunteers. For one thing, it makes it tougher to push for a pay raise when people are offering to do your job for free. But departments also know that you get what you pay for. What is the point of background checks, psychological tests and the professional training police undergo if a person can donate a few grand and go out on patrol? Some people are a little too eager to be police officers. These people perhaps buy a police-like car for their personal car. Maybe they put in a police light or two. Some have actually made car stops. Police departments hate cop impersonators (it's illegal, by the way) and try and weed them during the hiring process. You want workers who like the job, but not too much; there's a fine line between passion and fanaticism. That said, there are good volunteer police officers. New York City, for example, has auxiliary police. These officers received more limited training and they help with neighborhood events and other nonenforcement activities. They wear an NYPD uniform but do not carry a gun. Auxiliary police and similar programs reinforce the notion that the police are the public and the public are the police. Volunteers remind us all that policing is a noble public calling, and most police work does not have to be done by overly militarized SWAT officers. An auxiliary program also allows young recruits a way to dip their foot into the police world before taking the plunge. It can be a great benefit to everybody when potential officers discover the job isn't for them before they are locked into a 20-year commitment. What happened in Tulsa County is a disgrace to police professionalism, and the fallout from this disaster may push police departments to end these kinds of programs. That would be a mistake. Police departments should encourage more productive interactions between police and the public. But a line does need to be drawn.
response: Robert Bates, a 73-year-old reserve deputy sheriff and insurance company CEO, fatally shot Eric Harris during a confrontation that he mistook for a police operation. Bates, who had volunteered in various community events and over 100 operations with the violent crimes task force, was not authorized to carry a gun during such activities. The incident raises questions about the vetting process for reserve deputies and the potential for conflicts of interest due to donations from individuals like Harris. Bates's actions highlight the need for clear guidelines and background checks to ensure the safety and integrity of law enforcement, even in volunteer roles. The incident in Tulsa County underscores the importance of maintaining professional standards and the potential risks of allowing unpaid volunteers to participate in law enforcement activities.

source_info: London (CNN)British police investigating a spectacular heist in the heart of London's jewelry district said Friday they knew a burglar alarm went off but didn't respond. Southern Monitoring Alarm Company called the Metropolitan Police Service, also known as Scotland Yard, at 12:21 a.m. April 3 to report that the burglar alarm had been activated at Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd., MPS said in a prepared statement. "The call was recorded and transferred to the police's CAD (computer-aided dispatch) system," the statement said. "A grade was applied to the call that meant that no police response was deemed to be required. We are now investigating why this grade was applied to the call. This investigation is being carried out locally. "It is too early to say if the handling of the call would have had an impact on the outcome of the incident." The theft was so big that police haven't come up with a value for what was stolen. Over the four-day Easter holiday, thieves broke into the vault of Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. and might have been able to take as long as four days to rifle through the boxes. A former police official in London has speculated that the loss could run to £200 million, or $300 million, in a remark widely reported by news media. Numerous British news organizations put the value of the loss in the hundreds of thousands of pounds. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Johnson of the London Metropolitan Police Flying Squad said police were still identifying the owners of ransacked safe deposit boxes and trying to contact them to learn what had been lost. The British tabloid The Daily Mirror claimed Friday to have obtained closed-circuit TV footage that captured the robbery being carried out. The video showed people inside the building dressed like utility workers with their faces covered. They carried large bags, what looked like drill equipment and other tools, then exited with trash bins. Toward the end of the video, a white van can be seen on a street during daytime with individuals loading back their gear and the trash bins. British police told CNN they have not released any video of the heist. When asked about the video published by the Daily Mirror, police said they could not confirm that it was footage from the Hatton Garden robbery and that officers have not seen that particular video. The Daily Mirror published time-stamped images it said showed that the thieves had been -- as was feared -- in the vault for days. The Mirror's time stamps, which CNN has not been able to independently verify, show employees locking up for the weekend at 9:19 p.m. on Thursday. If the footage, and its interpretation by the newspaper are correct, at least six people were involved in the heist. Just four minutes later, the first of the thieves, nicknamed "Mr. Ginger" by the newspaper for his red hair, appears in the building holding a black bag. He goes downstairs toward the vault. At 9:27 p.m., a street camera shows a white Ford Transit van pulling up to an alley beside the Hatton Garden Safe Deposit building. Men are seen dragging trash bins down the alley before the van drives away, leaving the men behind. Inside the building, at 9:30p.m., the camera records a thief nicknamed "The Gent" for his natty clothing -- though he also wears a hard-hat and a high-visibility jacket labeled "Gas" on the back. A minute later, "Mr. Strong" appears, wearing a builder's hat and carrying steel supports, which the newspaper speculates could have been used to support the diamond-tipped drill used to smash through the wall of the vault. At 9:36 p.m., Mr. Strong and a thief nicknamed Mr. Montana for the logo on his hooded sweatshirt roll in trash bins, one of which might have contained, according the Mirror, the 77-pound drill that bored through the reinforced seven-foot concrete wall to reach the vault. It is unclear, but the thieves may have spent the night in the basement in or near the vault. At any rate, according to the Daily Mirror, no more activity is seen above ground until Friday morning, shortly before 8:00. The white van returns, is loaded in two minutes, and drives off again. On Saturday evening, Mr. Ginger returns, two days after he was first seen. The newspaper says is wearing latex gloves and carrying a black sack. He goes downstairs toward the vault. Saturday evening also marked the first appearance of the Tall Man, who helped carry some of the loot out of the building. Early Sunday, Mr Ginger, the Tall Man and a robber nicknamed the Old Man are seen to be active. The Tall Man and the Old Man struggle to move a bin before they drag it outside. The Old Man leans on the bin, struggling for breath, and reveals the side of his face to the camera. A white van arrives by the alley and the men start loading equipment on it, including several trash bins. Three men get into the white van and, at 6:44 a.m. they are gone. The heist would not be reported to police for two more days, on Tuesday morning when employees of the company arrived for work. Police said Thursday there was no sign of forced entry. Johnson said the thieves appeared to have gained access to the vault through the shaft of an elevator that is used by several businesses in the building. The thieves disabled the elevator on the second floor of the building -- which would be called the third floor in the United States -- then climbed down the elevator shaft into the basement, he said. Once there, he said, they used a drill to bore through a 6-foot-thick wall and gain access to the vault where the safe deposit boxes were. People with knowledge of the area have speculated that cash and jewels were probably taken. Some jewelry businesses reportedly stored some of their jewels in the boxes rather than leaving it in their stores over the holiday weekend. Johnson said the scene in the vault remained chaotic as police continued their forensic examination. He said the floor was covered with dust and littered with safe deposit boxes and power tools. WATCH: Top five jewelry heists. Johnson called the crime sophisticated and said there were a limited number of people in the United Kingdom capable of pulling it off. He said he had no idea whether the thieves were still in the country. Although there was no sign of forced entry to the building, the detective said, "whether that involves inside knowledge will form part of the investigation." Hatton Garden is a storied area in London and the heart of the city's diamond trade. The area's promotional website says it is home to "the largest and most concentrated cluster of jewellery retailers in the UK" and has been for quite some time. "History tells us that the old City of London had certain streets -- or quarters -- dedicated to specific types of business," the website says. "The Hatton Garden area has been the epicentre of London's jewellery trade since medieval times. "Today, it maintains its international reputation as the centre of London's diamond trade. It is one of the finest and most renowned jewellery locations in the world." How was $4.8 million in gold swiped from a North Carolina highway? The website of Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. says the company was founded in 1954 and offers a "secure and cost-effective solution to store and protect important and irreplaceable personal belongings."
response: A major heist took place in London's Hatton Garden jewelry district, where thieves stole an unspecified amount of valuable items from the Hatton Garden Safe Deposit Ltd. vault during the Easter holiday. Southern Monitoring Alarm Company reported the burglar alarm as activated at 12:21 a.m. on April 3, but no police response was dispatched. Detective Chief Inspector Paul Johnson of the Metropolitan Police is investigating why the call was graded as not requiring a response. The thieves, who dressed as utility workers and wore masks, had access to the vault for up to four days, using drilling equipment to break through a reinforced concrete wall. The Daily Mirror published CCTV footage showing the robbery, but police have not confirmed its authenticity. The area is a hub for the UK's diamond trade and has been a target for sophisticated heists.

source_info: Los Angeles (CNN)She's one of the hottest and most successful Latinas in Hollywood, but now Sofia Vergara is playing defense in a legal battle initiated by her ex-fiance: He wants to keep the two frozen embryos from their relationship, both female. The 42-year-old actress and star of the hit TV sitcom "Modern Family" split from businessman Nick Loeb in May 2014. Loeb is suing the Colombian-born actress in Los Angeles to prevent Vergara from destroying their two embryos conceived through in vitro fertilization in November 2013, according to published reports by New York Daily News and In Touch magazine. The lawsuit cited by the two publications, however, lists the plaintiff as "Joe Doe" and the defendant as "Jane Doe." The suit doesn't identify the names of the actual litigants. Instead, the suit asks the court to advance the matter anonymously to protect the two individuals' privacy. The two publications cited unidentified sources in their reports. On Tuesday, Loeb's attorney Abram Moore confirmed in a statement that Loeb filed the lawsuit. Representatives for Vergara declined to comment. Court papers allege the couple created the embryos while they were engaged, and their plan was to eventually have children together. On "Modern Family," Vergara plays Gloria Delgado Pritchett, an eccentric and voluptuous Colombian immigrant who in recent episodes had a baby. But the sitcom make-believe is far from what Vergara is dealing with now. The lawsuit states the embryos should not be destroyed under any circumstances by Jane Doe until both parties reach an agreement. The suit also names as a defendant the clinic where the embryos are being held, the Art Reproductive Center in Beverly Hills. The center didn't respond to a message seeking comment Friday. According to the legal paperwork, the ex-couple had already used two surrogate mothers, one being a close friend of Jane Doe's, in an attempt to have children. However, neither of the implantations was successful. In his own statement, Loeb said he wants to implant the embryos in a surrogate and bring them to term, but he doesn't want any money from the egg donor. His statement doesn't directly identify Vergara as the donor, other than referring to his "ex." "I have previously offered to waive any parental or financial responsibilities or obligations on the part of my ex, and to even give her the opportunity to be involved with the child in the future, should she change her mind," Loeb said. He believes that "life begins at fertilization," he said. "Creating an embryo in the natural way can lead to parenthood obligations, even where a man doesn't want to become a father. Where a man does want to become a father, and wants to impose no obligations on the other party, he should have that corresponding right.  However life comes to be created, it should have no determination on either the rights of wanting to be or the requirements of having to be a parent," Loeb said. In an interview with ABC in April 2013, while the couple was still engaged, Vergara spoke of how she helped create embryos and what motivated her to do it. "We just wanted to plan ahead. My boyfriend Nick is three years younger than me and he's never had a son. I have my son, Manolo, so it's not that import(ant)... you know, it's not like an emergency for me to have another kid. For Nick, yes, because he's never had a baby," Vergara said. During the interview she seemed excited about wanting children with Loeb. "I already froze some eggs so, you know, I wanted to take advantage of science. Why not?" Vergara said. The ABC anchor asked Vergara how far along she was in the process, to which the actress replied: "I took them out already. They're in a refrigerator." Laughing, she added, "Hopefully they'll be fresh by the time I use them." The case has led to questions about who has the right to embryos. Typically, a prior legal agreement between a couple spells out who has ultimate authority, said fertility specialist Dr. David Tourgeman, who's not involved in this case. "Usually when embryos are created, whether the couple is married or just consenting adults, there's usually a power of attorney that is described to these embryos, if they are frozen for future use," he said. In most cases, the mother or the origin of the egg is given power of attorney, although anyone can make a request, Tourgeman said. If there's a disagreement, the courts usually get involved to decide who legally owns the embryos, he said. "The documents that were signed during the fertility process will probably only apply in the case of death of one of the partners," he said. "In the scenario where there's a disagreement as to who these embryos belong to, it will usually be decided by a court of law." But experts say this lawsuit is bringing up a lot of interesting issues. "Religious, moral issues, to legal and contract issues. When does life begin? Are these embryos alive?" said California attorney Vance Owen. "To Catholics, for example, conception marks the beginning of life. To abortion advocates, the child has to be in a more advanced state, perhaps the third trimester, so it's a very interesting time to be discussing these life issues," Owen said. Owen said Loeb has a case because no court in California will allow the destruction of the embryos if both parties disagree. "This case is a gray area of law because it's new," Owen said. "It's developing as we speak," he said. "It's a question, I think, of whether to decide if these frozen (embryos)are human beings or whether they are property. Since they are unborn, some states in the United States look at these (embryos) not as life, but as property." Owen said the lawsuit reportedly filed by Loeb will now open new issues, and a California court will have to decide to whom the embryos belong. "These embryos are not inside her body," he said. "They are in a nitrogen tank in a clinic in Beverly Hills, so there the Planned Parenthood of Central Missouri vs. Danforth case cannot be used by the Sofia Vergara team to allege that the (embryos) would present some danger to her health as they did in that case." In that case, the U.S. Supreme Court declared a statute that requires parental and spousal consent for abortions to be unconstitutional. The lawsuit comes as Vergara promotes her new movie, "Hot Pursuit," with co-star Reese Witherspoon. Vergara is now reportedly engaged to actor Joe Manganiello. CNN's Krecyte Villarreal and Stella Chan contributed to this report.
response: Sofia Vergara, the star of "Modern Family," is embroiled in a legal dispute with her ex-fiancé, Nick Loeb, over the fate of two frozen female embryos created through in vitro fertilization in 2013. The actress, who is currently engaged to actor Joe Manganiello, and Loeb, who filed the lawsuit anonymously, are in a battle over the embryos, with Loeb seeking to prevent Vergara from destroying them. The lawsuit, which was filed in Los Angeles, involves the Art Reproductive Center in Beverly Hills, where the embryos are stored. Loeb, who believes that life begins at fertilization, wants to have the embryos implanted in a surrogate and raised as his own, without financial obligations to Vergara. Vergara, who has previously discussed her intentions to have children with Loeb, is now defending the embryos' disposal. This case raises complex questions about the legal status of embryos, including whether they are considered property or living beings, and the rights of individuals to control their reproductive choices. Experts note that courts typically weigh religious, moral, and contractual issues when deciding such matters, and this case could set precedents in California.

source_info: This week, Hillary Clinton surprised the world yet again — not with the official launch of her campaign but for the unconventional way she did it. She sure pushed the envelope. With her video, new logo and road trip, she opened a long communications campaign not only to "rebrand" herself but to completely reframe who she is, what she stands for and how she intends to run. We'll find out over the next year and a half whether it will work. Many in the press and on late-night television scratched their heads this week; others were scathing. Ruth Marcus --  a  columnist for the Washington Post -- dismissed her launch video as a "relentlessly, insultingly vapid" effort of "demographic box-checking." Jon Stewart lampooned it as a "State Farm commercial gone viral" and also "boring as s---." Since the media will likely be the stand-in primary opponent for Hillary, their belief in her authenticity is a critical factor in whether she can reframe herself in voter's eyes. But from a marketing perspective, her launch may have been much more successful than critics think. The YouTube announcement video took on the central strategic challenge for the campaign and candidate: To flip Clinton's message from self-absorbed "I" to empathetic "we." While critics may sneer, it is hard to deny that the image it projects of Hillary is more confident, fresher, simpler and forward-looking, with even a bit of the upstart feel of two of the most successful product launch companies, Nike and Apple. Clinton's team may have begun to create an empathetic relationship with voters that has eluded her in the past, most crucially when she lost the nomination fight to Barack Obama in 2008. In marketing terms, rebranding is a strategy to bring a new name, term, symbol or design to an established brand with the aim of developing a new identity in the minds of consumers. Reframing is a strategy that goes further: it seeks to change how a consumer (or voter) emotionally experiences an established brand. A rebrand may change how you think about a brand; a reframe may change how you feel about it.  In the Apple case, the company at one time fell on its face when it unveiled the original Macintosh; some thought the company was headed for oblivion. But when Steve Jobs returned as CEO, he went back to the drawing board and soon unveiled the iPod, which not only changed the way consumers thought about Apple, but how they experienced it. Not only a rebrand -- but a reframe. Take Hillary's road trip to Iowa in the van nicknamed Scooby. The press lampooned her, but I would bet that for many others, her unscripted and anonymous stop at Chipotle reinforced the "everyday Americans" campaign theme. Hillary stood in line to order, an everyday customer among everyday people at an everyday fast-food chain. Also introduced last week was what will come to be the single most-ubiquitous element of her campaign: Clinton's new and controversial  campaign logo. It is a brilliant, iconic expression of the emotional connection she wants people to have with her, her message and her movement.  In fact, her logo is all about movement. Simple, confident, high tech and shorthand to a much younger set of voters, the bold red arrow moving left to right in front of the strong blue H says it all: You are the important ones. I'm here to support you with everything I've got. Let me help you move forward. Taken together, all the pieces of Clinton's announcement -- as well as the unconventional media she used to deliver them -- bring her back on stage not as a leader from yesterday but, surprisingly, as one for the future. Coincidentally, the way Marco Rubio announced his run for the Republican nomination most likely amplified the impact of Clinton's reframing. For all his posturing about being the new generation, Rubio followed to a "T" the most traditional script for announcing a candidacy: traditional stage and podium, dark suit, bright tie, wife and kids on camera, a live speech, all about himself, timed for the evening news. Rubio's logo, the signature of his image, drew immediate criticism for being amateurish and unconsidered, even leaving Alaska and Hawaii off the map of America. In stark contrast, Hillary showed the confidence and finesse to buck tradition on every front. It was Hillary who pulled the ultimate jiu-jitsu. There are those, of course, who will be alienated, if not disgusted, by the way her campaign has unfurled such a sophisticated marketing plan. In a day when voters are yearning for authenticity, how do we know this is the real Hillary or a candidate in a mask?  Fair question. But for better or worse, mass marketing has become the staple of presidential campaigns -- that's where most campaign dollars go. Both sides know how to play, sometimes brilliantly.  Remember the Reagan advertisements of 1984, proclaiming "Morning in America"? What we know is that over time, voters see a lot of unscripted moments of a candidate where the real character comes through. And if they spot hypocrisy between ads and the candidate, that campaign will get into trouble fast. That's why the key to Hillary Clinton's success in reframing her message and movement will be consistency.  She must not only take the essence of a humble, empathic relationship with voters and integrate it into all elements of her communication, she must also live it every day. Otherwise there will be messaging "schizophrenia," the solid start with flashes of brilliance will peter out and she'll be facing the same voter perceptions that doomed her race in 2008. In the meantime, one can imagine Clinton getting a huge, satisfying belly laugh out of the early returns on her efforts.
response: Hillary Clinton has launched her campaign with a novel and ambitious reframing strategy, aiming to change how voters perceive her. Her approach, featuring a video, new logo, and road trip, is designed to move from a self-absorbed "I" to an empathetic "we," and project a confident, fresh image. Critics have been divided, with some labeling it vapid and others dismissing it as unoriginal. However, from a marketing perspective, Clinton's campaign has successfully repositioned her as a forward-looking, relatable leader, akin to successful product launches by Nike and Apple. The new logo, with its bold red arrow and blue H, emphasizes her commitment to supporting voters and moving forward. While some may view this as a sophisticated marketing plan, the key to her success lies in consistency and authenticity. Clinton must ensure that her message and actions align, avoiding "schizophrenia" and maintaining a humble, empathetic approach to connect with voters on a deeper level. Her unconventional launch, while critiqued, has already made a significant impression, positioning her as a candidate for the future.

source_info: The Dark Knight returns... again. "The Dark Knight Returns," published in 1986, is widely credited for resurrecting Batman in pop culture, something we've seen referenced in everything from 1989's "Batman" to the "Dark Knight" trilogy and the upcoming "Batman v. Superman: Dawn of Justice." Now popular comic book writer Frank Miller is returning to his best-known story. DC Comics (a Time Warner company, like CNN) announced Friday the final chapter in his "The Dark Knight Returns" trilogy, in the form of "The Dark Knight III: The Master Race" ("The Dark Knight Strikes Again" was released in 2001). This third chapter in the grim saga will be released sometime in the fall. "Batman remains my favorite comic book hero and a sequel to Dark Knight is going to be daunting," said Miller in a press release, "but we'll do our best." Miller will be joined by acclaimed artist Brian Azzarello.
response: Frank Miller, creator of "The Dark Knight Returns," returns with its third, final installment, "The Master Race," in fall 2016.

source_info: Every morning, Sissa Abu Dahou puts on traditional male dress, known as a jalabiya, and heads into the streets of the Egyptian city of Luxor for a day of hard work. But this man of the house is actually a woman. The grandmother of two has dressed as a man for 43 years to avoid oppression and eek out a living in the conservative Muslim state. "Why did you do this mother?" her daughter asked during a recorded interview with Egyptian television network CBC. "Your father died and I was six months pregnant with you." she replied. "None of my siblings helped me. I raised you and sent you to school. Without money I could not have gotten you an education." A widow at just 21, Dahou was forced to fend for herself in Egypt's patriarchal south, where decades ago it was unheard of for women to earn their own living. Even in recent years, women make up barely 24% of Egypt's workforce, according to the World Bank. "It is considered wrong that I dressed as a man but no one can judge. Not you or anyone else. Only God can judge me," Dahou said, "People talked but I said I decided to be a man so I can take care of my small daughter." The breadwinner worked as a brick maker for just 25 piasters, the equivalent of a few cents, until she saved up enough money to buy a shoeshine kit.  She found a place for her wooden box, painted with red hearts and the Egyptian flag, alongside the all-male shoe shiners of her community. "If it wasn't for my mother, I would have been on the streets" Houda, her daughter, told TV host Mona al-Shazly through tears. "Honestly I would have been in the streets. I did not find a home except with my mother. And even today my children rely on her." The years of sun and sand weathered and darkened Dahou's face and left her with a voice so deep and raspy she can easily be mistaken for a man. Her only child, Houda, eventually married and had two children of her own. Through the years the one-time housewife dreamed of owning her own business one day, a small street stand to sell snacks and cigarettes.  After her interview on CBC television, the governor of Luxor province offered Dahou a kiosk and a cash advance. The maverick had one requirement- she would only agree to meet with the governor in male attire. "Even if I die, I will not take it off," Dahou said as she pulled on the male jalabiya in front of a TV camera, "When I had to dress in a woman's jalabiya when I went to Cairo I felt suffocated. No, I thank God. I don't want anyone to look at me or look at my daughter." Now the 65-year-old who earned respect as a man has gained praise as a woman. Egypt's President, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, crowned her as one of Egypt's ideal mothers in an official ceremony last month. "If I was really a man, I would not have done this," Dahou told her daughter, "I would have gotten remarried. I would have left you who knows where. You would have been treated without dignity or left homeless. Thank God I was able to protect you."
response: Sissa Abu Dahou, a 65-year-old widow in Luxor, Egypt, has dressed as a man for 43 years to avoid societal oppression and support her family. Forced to fend for herself after her husband's death and with limited family support, Dahou worked as a brick maker and later as a shoe shiner. She saved enough to buy a kiosk and was recently offered a government-sponsored business. Despite facing criticism, Dahou's deep commitment to her daughter, Houda, has earned her respect and praise, including recognition as one of Egypt's ideal mothers by President Abdel Fattah el-Sisi. Her story highlights the challenges faced by women in conservative Muslim societies and the resilience required to support their families.

review_info.review_text:
We ordered mixed veg spicy, butter chicken medium spicy, roti and naan. All were awesome. 

Tasty Food. Great service.

Restroom needs some attention

Service was great and food was delicious. review_info.review_text: Very fresh and tasty, I would come back again for the sweet berry crepes, so good
Delicious strawberry rhubarb crepe, and friendly service in a quaint shop.

I recently had the misfortune of suffering through one of the BLT crepes. response: The Le Crepe Shoppe, located at 15 W Gutierrez St in Santa Barbara, CA, offers a delightful French cuisine experience with a casual ambiance. The creperies are recognized for their fresh and tasty dishes, particularly the sweet berry and strawberry rhubarb crepes, which have been praised by customers. The shop also provides take-out services and offers street parking, making it convenient for patrons. However, the romantic or intimate setting is not the focus, and reservations are not accepted. review_info.review_text:
What a great brunch. A couple days ago my wife randomly decided she'd book a hotel in Santa Barbara for the weekend. She said she had already found a good spot for brunch Sunday morning. Usually I plan all the trips so she had a lot of pressure not to disappoint. And... she did not. Moral of the story: here we are now, just enjoyed a delicious breakfast burrito (her) and steak/eggs/frites (me). Most importantly the "mimosa madness" was served just the way I like it, just a splash of juice. This may have influenced this review :)
Our server Jamie was awesome and very hospitable. 5 stars for food, ambiance, and service. We'll be back some day.
main downside is that the food was overpriced. taste and quality of the food was great and service was also good. ambiance is nice, the restaurant is located in a hotel lobby.

The best bottomless brunch! $14 for the first mimosa, and $1 for every mimosa after that. 

We came on a Sunday for brunch and we didn't have to wait which was nice. The restaurant is inside a VERY nice hotel, and I was shocked at how cheap the menu is, given how nice the ambiance is. 

Our server Matthew was great. We were in SB for the day and he was giving us tips on what to do & where to go. He was very outgoing & kind, and the service was fast and on point. 

The food was good as well, I got the eggs benedict and it was filling & delicious. The mimosas were BOMB and so cheap... we paid only $16 each for bottomless! They also have different flavors: orange, grapefruit, and poinsettia/cranberry which were all v tasty. 

DEFINITELY recommend this place to anyone looking for a good bottomless brunch!

response:
Finch & Fork is a charming American restaurant located in Santa Barbara, CA, nestled within the elegant Hotel Santa Barbara. This establishment offers a delightful blend of Breakfast & Brunch, American (New), and Traditional cuisines, alongside a vibrant Nightlife and Bars scene. Open from 5:30 PM to 11:00 PM on weekdays and 9:00 AM to 2:00 PM on Sundays, it provides ample opportunities for both casual and romantic dining experiences. 

The restaurant boasts several notable features, including free WiFi, business parking (garage, street, and valet), and the ability to make reservations. Despite its upscale ambiance, the service remains warm and welcoming. The food quality is highly praised, with standout dishes like the bottomless brunch, which offers a $14 starter mimosa and $1 refills, making it a budget-friendly yet luxurious experience. The service is exceptional, with staff like Jamie and Matthew providing impeccable hospitality and helpful recommendations. 

While some reviewers mention that the food can be slightly overpriced, the overall experience is universally praised for its excellent food, ambiance, and service. Whether you're a local or a visitor, Finch & Fork offers a memorable and enjoyable dining experience that is sure to leave a lasting impression. With an average rating of 4.0 stars, the restaurant is a must-visit for anyone looking to enjoy a top-notch meal in Santa Barbara.

review_info.review_text: Found this gem bopping around the neighborhood, thankfully we did! It was really good food food and the woman making it was gem! I'll be more than happy to go back!

Amazing!!!! Such great food. The nachos were incredible and the service was great. My wife eats low carb and she got the bowl with no rice and it tasted healthy and delicious. I recommend getting fresh avocado in place of the guacamole sauce for the extra charge on the nachos. It's like 1.50 extra but so worth it!!! We will be back next time we are in SB.

The owner Efren (from Michoacán), allowed me to have dinner and a cold beer after they were closing (slow
Monday night). He made me a plate of Chile Verde (pork), very tasty.

response: Su Casa Fresh Mexican Grill is a highly-rated Mexican restaurant in Santa Barbara, CA, boasting a 4.5-star rating and exceptional customer reviews. review_info.review_text: My husband and I came to Tinkers for the first time about a month ago and we have become regulars. Today we ordered a Sourdough Bacon Cheeseburger and a double cheeseburger with an egg. Best burgers we've ever had!! Thank you Tinkers.

I really wanted this placed to be great, unfortunately that was not the case. There were two orders a head of mine yet it took approximately 30 minutes to prepare two burgers, fries and a corn dog. The food was good, but not above average. All that being said, I would've returned if the service had been better. Not only did the food take forever, but I practically had to beg the cashier for extra ketchup which was ridiculous considering there was only one small pre poured container in the bag. So was the person eating the corn dog supposed to dip their corn dog in the small container and the rest us just pass it around sparingly? The cashier just passive aggressively stared at me and blinked multiple times when I asked for extra ketchup. Given that it's a small spot I even tipped on my order takeout order to help support small businesses. I wanted so badly for this to be my go spot, but given the excessive wait times, value for price and not so great service, it will instead be a one and done.

We stopped here on our way to LA and the food was just EXCELLENT!... the double cheeseburger and fries were superb!! as well as the freeze and malt... this is definitively a hidden gem in the small beach town of Summerland.

response:
Tinker's Burgers, located at 2275 Ortega Hill Rd, Ste C in Summerland, CA, is a charming and popular burger joint that appeals to both casual diners and groups. review_info.review_text: Nice little place in downtown Santa Barbara where we stopped for late lunch/early dinner on our way back home to San Diego. We loved our flatbreads. I had been craving clam chowder and ordered it here. It was a little thick for my liking, but tasted good. Nice, friendly upscale casual place on State Street.

I had high hopes for this place, but it fell flat big time. I ordered the BLAT with grilled chicken and a side salad. I specifically asked for no tomato and they put tomato on both the sandwich and the salad. Not a huge deal, just annoying to pick it all off. And if you have an allergy, I would not trust this place to be mindful of that. The grilled chicken was not seasoned at all and the food overall was just extremely bland. My sandwich was stacked so high that the avocado all fell out as I was eating it. The side salad is lettuce, cucumber, red onion, and tomato. My bf got a burger with onion rings and he did not enjoy either part of the meal. The onion rings are beer battered and basically all batter. The burger was also unseasoned and not enjoyable. The service is ok. The staff is nice enough but my bf did have to get up and ask for his soda to be refilled and we were never offered a refill on our waters. We both left the restaurant with a stomach ache, I personally felt ill. I had stomach pains for a few hours afterwards and I can only assume it's because the food is not fresh because my meal didn't have any allergens that would've given me that reaction. Lastly, the cleaning spray they used on the tables just smelled funky. Idk how to explain it but we actually moved to an outside table because the inside one smelled so musty and mildewy.

The patio is nice, but not worth coming back for. Additionally, the menu is too scattered and overwhelming. I think they should stick to one type of food and work on increasing the quality rather than having too many different menu options that aren't cohesive.

We have been here a few times during trial over the past couple weeks and it is awesome.  I keep ordering the burrito but everyone seems to enjoy their food.  The one piece of feedback would be the Spanish soup seems to change - from not too spicy to spicy.

response:
Benchmark Eatery is an upscale casual American restaurant located at 1201 State St in Santa Barbara, CA. It offers a diverse menu including American (Traditional), American (New), Seafood, Vegetarian, and more, suitable for various dining occasions such as breakfast, brunch, lunch, and dinner. The restaurant provides free Wi-Fi, outdoor seating, and business parking with options in a garage, street, and lot. However, it does not offer reservations, and the service is described as okay but not exceptional, with one reviewer mentioning the need to ask for refills and the lack of attention to dietary restrictions.

Customer reviews are mixed, with some praising the flatbreads and clam chowder, while others describe the food as bland and poorly prepared, leading to stomach aches. One reviewer gave a 5-star rating, appreciating the burritos and the overall dining experience, though they noted inconsistencies in the Spanish soup's spiciness. Despite these issues, the ambiance is described as classy and casual, with a nice patio area, though one reviewer found the inside tables musty and mildewy.

Overall, Benchmark Eatery has a 4.0-star rating, indicating a generally positive experience, but with notable variations in food quality, service, and atmosphere. The restaurant is suitable for groups and is a good option for those looking for a nice, upscale casual dining experience in Santa Barbara.

review_info.review_text: While polite, the ammonia smell was dismissed when asked and also surprise!  There's a 35 dollar holding amount on pen tabs ( mine was 6 dollars at the end) that holds for 2 to 3 days. Something you'd think should be explained at the start of opening a tab. Especially if it's not busy. When called and asked about this mysterious 35 dollar charge it was met with a question of "the bartender didn't tell you about it? Further explication of why there is a 35 dollar hold was said "if someone can't pay their tab or leave before paying,  blah blah blah." I stopped caring. Was recommended to pay and close as I go or bring cash when drinking there. Unfortunately I will not be returning. Sorry you have less than great customers that cause you to HAVE to take 35 dollars out. Perhaps we evaluate. Good bye Uptown.

I attended a friend's birthday party at the Uptown and was so impressed with the staff, food and surroundings.

Seriously loved the whole experience. The staff couldn't have been more accommodating. Food was fresh & delicious, drinks were great.

Will be returning soon for happy hour with friends.
Great local treasure :)
Hands down my favorite pizza in town. The tri tip pizza is so worthwhile. Drinks are great and always an incredibly fun atmosphere.

Good location on the Mesa. Ambiance was nice outside. Service was great. The meat lovers flatbread was amazing, but I wasn't a big fan of the prosciutto flatbread.  The kids pasta was decent but it tasted very spicy for some reason. The mojito was decent, too. Will probably come back at some point!

Corner Tap is a welcome addition to the Mesa.  Staff are friendly and responsive. Should have ordered beer. Wine prices way too high. Paid $16 tonight for glass of Qupe Chardonnay which is pedestrian at best. Cauliflower hot and tasty. Flat bread cold and cheese not toasted. If you go, avoid wine and order one dish at a time!

response: The Corner Tap Room, located at 1905 Cliff Dr in Santa Barbara, CA, is a vibrant gastropub that offers a delightful blend of American (New) and American (Traditional) cuisine. Known for its extensive selection of craft beers, the establishment provides a warm and inviting atmosphere, especially outdoors, making it perfect for groups and casual dining. The menu features a variety of dishes, including Teriyaki Sliders, meat lovers flatbread, and kid's pasta, with a mix of positive and mixed reviews. While some patrons praise the delicious food and friendly service, others find the wine prices to be quite high. Despite this, the Corner Tap Room stands out for its excellent location, extensive beer selection, and welcoming ambiance, making it a popular spot for both locals and visitors.

review_info.review_text:
We came here to eat and grab drinks while waiting for our hotel room to be ready.  This restaurant is located in the Hyatt hotel.  

We ordered Lamb meatballs, which was delicious and flavorful.  We also shared a Bistro burger, which contained bacon, cheese, mixed greens, tomato, onions and brioche bun.  The patty was juicy and tender.  

I ordered a fruity cocktail, but I can't recall the name of it.  The cocktail  contained berries and it wasn't too strong, but had enough alcohol.  My other half got a mojito and said it was a great tasting cocktail.  

Our server, Edgar was really attentive and gave us great recommendations.  

Also, if you check in on Yelp, you get 50% off an item when you purchase an entree.  

*Parking- you can either park at the hotel for $25 a night and walk to this restaurant for find street parking*

Also, Happy Hour is from 4pm-7pm daily- small plates are $5, all beers are $4, all house wine are $5 and all well cocktails are $6 or Bartender's choice cocktail for $8.

The waiter specifically suggested "the salmon dish".

The dish cooked too dry and was not fresh.

There are fish bones in the meat.

So not sure if they the restaurant was under contruction or whatever but happy hour ended up being at the bar area by the pool. Which was fine with us. 

We got the brussel sprouts which were really tasty. We got the wings which had a thick herb topping on it. The wings were crispy and good but the herb topping and sauce were kind of lacking. We also got a salad that I cant remember in detail but I remember there were apples in it. It was crisp and refreshing. The drinks were kind of weak which was disappointing.

response:
Bistro 1111, located at 1111 E Cabrillo Blvd in Santa Barbara, CA, is a upscale American restaurant that specializes in breakfast, brunch, and American cuisine with a new twist. It offers a classy ambiance and is well-suited for groups, though it does not have outdoor seating or WiFi. Reservations are accepted, and the restaurant is open daily from 6:30 AM to 10:00 PM. While it doesn't have business parking, valet parking is available, and parking near the hotel or on the street is also an option. The restaurant offers takeout and has a happy hour from 4 PM to 7 PM daily with specials on small plates, beers, wine, and cocktails.

Customer reviews are mixed. A 2016 review praises the Lamb meatballs and Bistro burger, noting excellent service from the attentive server Edgar and the restaurant's Happy Hour promotions. However, a 2015 review criticizes the salmon dish for being dry and full of fish bones. Another review from 2015 mentions that the restaurant might have been under construction, which led to a change in the Happy Hour location but still highlights tasty brussel sprouts and a crisp apple salad, though the drinks were weak.

Despite the mixed reviews, Bistro 1111 offers a good dining experience with a strong emphasis on service and special promotions, making it a worthwhile visit for those in the area.

review_info.review_text: Went here on weekend get away. Service is friendly. Do be prepared to chill as is very laid back. Boyfriend and I both had the Caesar salad and the Huli Huli Chicken dish. AWESOME!! It was SO fantastic we couldn't stop thinking about it! Our neighbors (at the next table) were raving about how delicious their meals were too! Micro brews yummy! Highly recommend a visit here! I will definitely return if I visit the area again!
Love the food and atmosphere here when we visited a year and a half ago. But I just walked by here today and it looks to be CLOSED for good. What a shame.
Wish I could've reviewed the food!  Got there an hour and 20 min before closing and was told the kitchen is closed before they're out of food. Also took about 5 min to be acknowledged by anyone.

response: Pace food+drink, located at 413 State St in Santa Barbara, CA, is an American New-style restaurant known for its casual ambiance and friendly service. Established in a laid-back environment, it offers a variety of dishes, including the highly-praised Caesar salad and Huli Huli Chicken, alongside microbrews that add to the overall dining experience. The restaurant supports group dining and takeout, but does not offer reservations, outdoor seating, or Wi-Fi. Parking is available on the street without validation, and the atmosphere is best described as casual. Despite a recent closure announcement, many customers have left excellent reviews, praising the food and service, while a few have had less positive experiences, highlighting issues with service and availability. Despite these issues, the restaurant maintains a strong reputation for its casual, inviting atmosphere and delicious American cuisine.

source_info.name: Riverbench Santa Barbara Tasting Room
source_info.categories: Wine Bars, Wine Tasting Room, Wineries, Beer, Wine & Spirits, Arts & Entertainment, Nightlife, Bars, Food

review_info.review_text: Girl friends and I made an unplanned stop at Riverbench and were blown away by the amazing time we had during our tasting, especially their sparkling brut rosé, I had to write a review for our pourer Jordie, who took very good care of us and was extremely passionate and knowledgeable about their products. She took the time to explain in detail each wine we chose for our flights. We also had 3 small dogs with us and she came out with dog treats to make sure they weren't forgotten. Also, the chocolate truffles were to die for. Needless to say we had an amazing time and left with a couple bottles of their fantastic wines and sparkling rosé. Definitely coming back the next time we're in Santa Barbara!

Fantastic wine tasting experience with great patio vibes!! We came here before our dinner over at The Lark and had a wonderful time tasting some exceptional wine. We were helped by Jordy (sp?) who provided us with an exceptional wine tasting experience and was super nice and fun to talk to. We posted up on their patio and first tasted a few of their bubbles. We both LOVE champagne/sparkling and since we each got our own tasting we got to try a good variety...our favorite was probably the 2017 Blanc de Blancs! We then moved on to try their Pinot Noirs and seriously every one we tried was phenomenal!! I went with the 2018 Estate, 2017 One Palm, and 2017 Pommard. On their menu it was explained the tasting notes go from a little lighter down to something a little more darker/bold in flavor so it was really fun to see and taste the difference as we worked our way down the list. We already had their wine club form filled out by the time we tried our first Pinot!! Everything we tasted up to that point was phenomenal and then you through in the excellent experience Jordy provided us and it was a no-brainer this was a winery we wanted to be part of and enjoy for years to come! This was also a special experience for us as we recently got engaged so being we visited one of the only places in Santa Barbara Wine Country to taste a bubble flight made our celebration even more perfect!! And speaking of celebrations, they also sell their sparkling wine in these glittered out sparkling bottles which would be a perfect gift for someone or something fun for the holidays. They have bottles already glittered-out in certain colors or if you request a color and give them a little less time, they can customize the glitter color for you. Such a cool add-on to offer!! Overall this was one of our favorite wine tasting experiences and we cannot wait to come back!!

Five stars for the wine! their Pinot noir's are spectacular. I just didn't love this place. Small tables with uncomfortable stools. Only two options for food are a cracker/salami/nut box or chocolate truffles.  I'm thinking the wine pores are 1.5 ounces and you get five of them for $25. Just doesn't seem like a great value in comparison to other places with a better atmosphere and food choices. Server was very knowledgeable about the wine and the wines themselves were amazing.

response: Riverbench Santa Barbara Tasting Room is a vibrant wine bar and winery located at 137 Anacapa St, Ste C in Santa Barbara, CA. Known for its exceptional wine selection, including a standout sparkling brut rosé and a variety of Pinot Noirs, it offers a memorable wine tasting experience. The tasting room features a lovely patio and a friendly, knowledgeable staff, particularly the pourer Jordie, who goes above and beyond to ensure a delightful visit, even for those with pets. While the wine quality is universally praised, some customers have noted the limited food options and the value of the tasting flights could be improved. Despite these minor drawbacks, Riverbench has a 4.0-star rating and is a must-visit for wine enthusiasts in Santa Barbara.

review_info.review_text:
Nestled off the main strip known as state street on West Carrillo, not far from the 101 freeway at all, this spot gives you a welcoming... you are at your place, kind of feel. Perhaps you can call it the CHEERS of Santa Barbara. The regular folks that come through will tell you that.

I was introduced to this place last night while checking things out around town. It's very clean, lighting is balanced and the mood is one which simply says "take a load off your shoulders and have a good time." The staff is extremely accommodating. Fran has worked with the establishment for a couple decades now and she's the epitome of the reason why Mel's Place has been around since 1963. 

My small clan shot the breeze with her for a while... we are on a call her by her handle basis now (visit this place and learn what it is for yourself). She filled us in on the history of the joint. She even cracked open the billiard room for us to squeeze in a game.

The game room features darts, pool among other things like a jukebox you can DJ for a reasonable cost. All in excellent condition.The menu has eats and drinks that are reasonably priced.

I read that this spot is closed and no longer in business. Visit and see for yourself that such is far from the truth. You can check out their website to learn more about it: www.melslounge.com

After your visit, I'm sure you'll have some nice things to put up on yelp about them too.
It's great that Mel's is back in a new place. But I still miss the dark little bar.

Super small local place to stop for a drink or two... or three. ;-)

Cost to worth it ratio: 4

Highlight:
- Dive bar in the middle of the trendy pedestrian mall in downtown Santa Barbara. Liked the juxtaposition of the overall location with nice stores and bars and this actual tiny dive bar hidden in between it all.
- Local's spot: because it's not like the others, a lot of locals hang here. Nice to get out of the touristy joints.
- Strong drinks that don't break the bank: you can always count on this from dive bars! The Captain and Cokes we ordered were mostly clear with just a tinge of caramel color. ;-)
- Mid daytime excitement: you get quite the characters to people watch and interact with--from hard core drinkers to free-loving travelers to a couple dancing happily like nobody's watching to jukebox music. 

Lowlights (my flip side to highlights):
- Really hot inside: small place with limited air flow
- If you're visiting the city probably wouldn't spend tons of time here, as a lot of places have patios, etc to enjoy the perfect Santa Barbara weather

I'd come back for a few drinks for a change of Santa Barbara pace. And my friends who live here like it and I'm usually with them.

response:
Mel's Place, nestled off West Carrillo Street in Santa Barbara, CA, is a beloved dive bar that has been a cornerstone of the local nightlife since 1963. This charming establishment, known for its cozy and intimate atmosphere, offers a welcoming and relaxed environment, perfect for taking a load off and enjoying a good time. With its excellent lighting, clean interior, and casual vibe, Mel's Place is a favorite among regulars and locals, providing a unique juxtaposition to the trendy pedestrian mall in downtown Santa Barbara.

The bar features a game room with darts, pool, and a DJ-able jukebox, all in excellent condition. The menu offers a variety of reasonably priced eats and drinks, making it a great spot for groups and casual get-togethers. The staff, particularly Fran, who has been with the bar for decades, is exceptionally accommodating and knowledgeable about the establishment's rich history.

Customers praise the bar for its strong drinks and the friendly, laid-back atmosphere. However, it's important to note that the bar can get quite warm, and the small space might not be ideal for extended visits during the day. Despite these minor drawbacks, Mel's Place remains a must-visit for those looking to experience the local flavor and unique charm of Santa Barbara. Overall, it's a great place to unwind, relax, and enjoy the company of like-minded individuals.

source_info.name: Pizza Mizza
source_info.categories: Food Delivery Services, Food, Restaurants, Pizza, Italian

review_info.review_text: Bummed only delivery now probably my favorite pizza in town everywhere else sucks and are making restaurants you feel like you almost have to dress up for now and over priced including the owners of Pizza Mizza new pizza restaurant on state

This pizza place is pretty average. They have a huge list of different kinds of pizzas, pastas, salads, and more! I recently tried to call an order in to pick up but was told they only do delivery right now so I ended up just doing delivery. I couldn't decide what to order with all of their different choices and sizes! They even have cauliflower and gluten free crust options!

I ended up getting the personal size Hawaiian pizza with a normal crust. It took about an hour to arrive at my house but when I finally got it I was so happy and hungry. The pineapple was fresh, along with the ham and the crust was cooked with the perfect amount of crisp! They also gave me multiple sides of ranch which I was stoked about since most places always never actually bring the ranch when you order it or give you only one.

They also gave me plates and cheese along with the hot peppers! Overall I had a great experience here getting delivery here and I can't wait to order them again! :)

I always wondered why this place had such average to low rating and after a few times of visiting this place, I can see why. Food is great! I have no complaints over their food. There used to be a Pizza Mizza in Ventura and I remember going there often so when I saw there was one in SB, I had to go give them a try.

As for customer service here...
I'm always left wondering if there's anyone in charge here or if any of the front staff even care about their job. This isn't my first time waiting here over 30minutes for food which is beyond ridiculous. I've ordered different things and they all take so long. I don't know if they're just short staffed but this is not acceptable in any restaurant business especially if this is a continuous problem. My boyfriend ordered a sandwich which they left sitting on their rack for 10min while my pasta was nowhere to be seen. I was sick of their tendency to just hang out, have conversations amongst each other, and not care about their hungry customers. I went to the front and asked them if that plate on the rack was for us and they said that it just came out and were waiting for my pasta to come out. That sandwich did NOT JUST come out but obviously they were too busy with their conversations to realize it was there. Whatever, I brought it to my table and we waited another 10 minutes for my pasta. I saw two plates again sitting on the rack for about 5mins and I told myself if none of those are mine, I'm going to leave. Well it turns out none of them were mine and one server who was aware of our situation came to notify us that due to the delay, he had refunded my entire bill. Great. So I'm still hungry. The food is most likely going to take more time. I got my money back. I'm not waiting anymore. So my boyfriend and I left. 

The food is so good that I would've given this place 5 stars but unfortunately, the staff is a big miss. Maybe management should train their staff again or hire people who actually care about their job.

response:
Pizza Mizza is a pizza restaurant located in Santa Barbara, CA, offering a wide range of Italian cuisine and catering to various dietary needs, including gluten-free and cauliflower crust options. The restaurant, which also serves as a food delivery service, is known for its casual ambiance and support of group dining, making it ideal for both casual and organized gatherings. It offers free WiFi, outdoor seating, and has a dedicated section for restaurant reservations, ensuring a comfortable and convenient dining experience.

Customer reviews are mixed, with some praising the quality of the food and the freshness of the ingredients, while others highlight significant issues with customer service and wait times. One reviewer noted that the food is exceptional but was disappointed with the long wait times, particularly with their order being delayed multiple times. Another reviewer appreciated the variety of options and the quality of the food, especially the personal-sized Hawaiian pizza with a perfectly cooked crust. However, a third reviewer expressed frustration with the slow service and the lack of responsiveness from the staff, suggesting that better training or hiring of more attentive employees could significantly improve the experience.

Despite these challenges, Pizza Mizza maintains a strong presence in the local community, offering a balanced and enjoyable dining experience with a focus on food quality and variety. The restaurant has a business rating of 3.5 stars, reflecting a generally positive but not flawless reputation. Overall, Pizza Mizza is a decent choice for pizza and Italian food, with the potential for a great experience if the service issues are addressed.

review_info.review_text:
Bought a axxess card, they refused to accept it. Don't order the
chicken piccata, there., they declined it,,   Especially, when you go to pay, you pay full price. So why did I get the card, and pay $ 40.00
Will I go back,?  well as a first time customer, chances are. ZERO
No second chances, and I would have been a steady customer.

We love, love, love Taffy's! We've had almost everything on the menu and have enjoyed every bite. There's no doubt about it that Taffy's is our favorite pizza in town, but we also love the great beer selection, bread sticks, salads, pastas and sandwiches. 

They have a HUGE selection of pizza breads, veggies toppings, cheeses and meats. Because they have such a variety of toppings, their sandwiches, salads, etc. have a great selection of toppings too. I called and accidentally asked to order an antipasto salad, not realizing that they don't even have an antipasto salad on the menu. However, they have such amazing customer service, that they assured me they have everything to make a great antipasto salad delivered to my house. And they were right!! It was incredible. 

AND free delivery, but call early to place your order. It can take a little while depending on when you call. So worth it for free delivery!! 

Pre-Covid times, they offered fun events like trivia on their large, private outdoor patio. I hope they can start that up again soon. 

They also have a small arcade room and lots of children's books scattered here and there for the kiddos. Very family friendly!

Fantastic pizza. Have been coming to taffy's for 20 years since I was a teenager and now bringing my kids here. Love it. Good food at reasonable price. Classic arcade in the back with some of the same games for the last 20 years.

response: Taffy's Pizza, located at 2026 De La Vina St in Santa Barbara, CA, is a beloved family-friendly restaurant known for its exceptional pizza and diverse menu. Established for over two decades, Taffy's offers a wide variety of pizzas, salads, sandwiches, and pasta, all made with high-quality ingredients. The restaurant's ambiance is casual, perfect for groups and families, with a fun arcade and children's books creating a welcoming atmosphere for kids. Taffy's provides free WiFi, outdoor seating, and parking options, making it a comfortable choice for dining out. While some customers have reported issues with accepting certain payment cards, many others rave about the exceptional service, especially in creating custom dishes like antipasto salads. The restaurant's commitment to quality and variety, combined with its family-friendly environment and free delivery, makes it a standout choice in Santa Barbara.

review_info.review_text:
Reasonable portions for a higher than expected price.

Chicken verde enchilada
Expected a massive plate piled with refried beans and rice but was pleasantly surprises at the very reasonable portion. I don't need all those fillers.

The dining room was nothing special, the service fine and the food ok. This is a solid 3 and good place to swing in and take a load off.
Too pricey for the enchiladas. Guacamole was fresh and tasty. Street Tacos were decent. Service was great...Very attentive and sincere.
Lovely burritos. My whole family loved them. Fresh ingredients and nice presentation . The staff is very friendly.

response:
Los Tarascos, located at 5915B Calle Real in Goleta, CA, is a Mexican restaurant offering a delightful dining experience with a casual ambiance. The restaurant accommodates groups and offers take-out services, with reservations available. Parking is available in a lot, and while there is no WiFi, the restaurant compensates with attentive and sincere service. Hours of operation vary, with extended hours on Fridays and Saturdays.

Customer reviews reflect a mixed experience. One reviewer praised the reasonable portions and fresh ingredients in the Chicken Verde Enchilada, despite the higher-than-expected price. Another diner found the enchiladas overpriced but appreciated the fresh guacamole and attentive service. A third reviewer, rating the burritos highly, noted the fresh ingredients, nice presentation, and friendly staff.

Overall, Los Tarascos is well-regarded for its casual atmosphere and family-friendly service, though prices may be a consideration for some. The restaurant maintains a 4.5-star rating based on the reviews, offering a solid dining experience for those seeking authentic Mexican cuisine.

review_info.review_text: Bad very bad servise the old lady to rude I left without  my  daily  coffe I gues she was in a bad mood shouldn't be workin there never came back

Wonderful experience with fresh, tasty doughnuts. What more could you ask for? My dad got these for us the morning after my sister's wedding and they were a yummy treat and great price. They are located in a very convenient location as well. Thank you!

I loved this shop when I'd lived Ventura. It's been 2 years since visiting but not having the option to return to my favorite restaurants has made me miss this wonderful little donut haven. The food is delicious & the employees are the salt of the earth. I'm really looking forward to coming back in a month.

response: Tyler's Donuts, located at 1002 Casitas Pass Rd in Carpinteria, CA, is a charming spot offering a delightful selection of donuts, coffee, and tea. The shop is open from 5:00 AM to 8:00 PM every day, making it a convenient choice for morning and late-night treats. It features free WiFi and a take-out service, catering well to both casual visits and group gatherings. While the parking situation is limited to street and a lot, the overall ambiance and customer service can vary significantly. One review highlights a negative experience with poor service, while others praise the fresh, tasty doughnuts and the shop's convenient location. With a 4.0-star rating, Tyler's Donuts offers a delightful dining experience, though service can sometimes be disappointing.

review_info.review_text: What the hell happened to this place???  In the past, they were very good and the items on the salad bar were tasty.  Now, this food is as bad as a small cheap casino off the Las Vegas strip.  First off, I went there last month and got the Malibu Chicken (similar to Chicken Cordon Bleu) and added a salad bar.  The Malibu Chicken was horrible.  It was like they reheated the fried chicken patty in the fryer and microwave the Swiss Cheese on top of the ham.  The salad bar is also BAD!!!  The soups tasted like they came out of a can, the salad was ok, not the best, and for the taco bar, I don't think the roaches would even come close to that.  Even the restrooms were disgusting and had a bad smell to them.  The only positive one star I will give them is there desert which is frozen ice cream/yogurt with hot fudge or butterscotch topping and chocolate sprinkles or Oreo cookie crumbles.  Overall, if you are hungry and want a good salad bar to go to, avoid this place at all costs and go over to Chuck's of Hawaii.  Thank god I have heard this place might be closing down this fall.  I wish though it was sooner!!!

This sizzler had bugs in the food. And the bathrooms are disgusting. I will be writing a letter to sizzler to let them know how how disappointed I was with a resteraunt I normally like. Don't eat here. I had to ask for a refund and leave.

The worst place I have ever been to for food!

Another place where I'm a regular which means I love this place! The food is really good & reasonably priced. Great for families. It reminds me of places I went to as a kid. The staff are some of the nicest people you'll meet.

response: Sizzler, located at 5555 Hollister Ave in Goleta, CA, is a traditional American steakhouse and seafood restaurant offering a casual and outdoor dining experience. The restaurant is known for its good food and family-friendly atmosphere, though it has garnered mixed reviews. One notable review highlights a significant decline in quality, with the Malibu Chicken and salad bar receiving harsh criticism, suggesting that the food has become subpar. Additionally, the reviewer noted issues with the cleanliness of the restrooms. Another reviewer mentioned bugs in the food and disgusting bathrooms, leading to a refund request. Despite these negatives, a 2011 review praises the food's quality and reasonable pricing, and commends the staff for their friendly service. Currently, Sizzler has a 3.0-star rating on the platform.

source_info.name: Goodland Kitchen
source_info.categories: Food, Local Services, Farmers Market, Professional Services, American (New), Restaurants, Shopping

review_info.review_text: They are open for takeout, great lunch menu, good chorizo good chips, huge salads. Very friendly service!
They just reopened!! Please come here and the market next door because I know this small business needs it! Amazing service and wonderful food :)

This place used to serve interesting well-prepared food. Not any more. It's all humdrum standard food, heavy on the meat, with little innovation. The great lunch specials, still listed on the website, are gone. The bread on my BLT seemed old and just pulled from the whole wheat wonderbread bag. There was only one choice for soup and it was done for the day. Really, no reason ever to come here again.

response: Goodland Kitchen is a culinary gem located at 231 S Magnolia Ave in Goleta, CA, offering a diverse menu that includes American (New) cuisine. Operating from Monday to Friday from 7:00 AM to 2:00 PM, the restaurant is accessible with street parking and provides outdoor seating. It is noted for its friendly service, classy yet casual ambiance, and is suitable for groups and takeout. Despite the positive reviews, the quality of food has been criticized for lacking innovation, with some customers noting that the standards have declined. However, the restaurant's commitment to community support and its welcoming atmosphere are highlighted by positive reviews. Overall, Goodland Kitchen is a place worth visiting for those who appreciate a well-executed, classy dining experience.

review_info.review_text: Always delicious, quality ingredients and in goos portions too, never not left satisfied from any Habit I've been to

Best burgers in town! Got a turkey burger with avocado and a little bit of bacon. Sooooo good! The bun was toasted to perfection. The people working there are always super kind and proactive. It always sounds like they are having a good time in all the rush.

This is an easy all around good hamburger place. There are options for kids and any adult with some healthy choices to go with it. I stick to the charburger with cheese or the steak sandwich, can't really be disappointed. There is also a kids meal that includes a great apple juice and fries for those kids who just have to have them! No matter what get the tempura green beans and onion rings; heck, you could skip the burgers and just have those!!! Easy parking and a buzzer if you want to wait in car with the kids.

response: Habit Burger Grill is a popular casual restaurant located at 3890 La Cumbre Plaza Lane in Santa Barbara, CA, serving up delicious burgers and other delightful dishes. The restaurant offers a variety of options, including kid-friendly meals and healthy choices, making it a great spot for families and groups. Guests frequently praise the quality ingredients and generous portions, with many reviewers mentioning that they are always satisfied with their visits. The friendly and proactive staff, especially during busy times, adds to the pleasant dining experience. While the restaurant does not offer indoor parking or WiFi, it does have an on-site parking lot and outdoor seating, which contributes to its casual and welcoming ambiance. Overall, Habit Burger Grill is a well-regarded choice for burger lovers in Santa Barbara.

review_info.review_text: I've finally found my sushi spot in town! & it's close to the newer Handlebar coffee. My husband only eats rice dishes and I love a little bit of both sushi and Japanese homey dishes. In most places in town, they are only good at one or the other. This place is great at both. The family feel of this restaurant is great. They were all so friendly and we felt really welcomed.  We can't wait to go back!  I've also had their food delivered and it travels really well.

Best santa barbara Uni sushi in United State.
An authentic hole in a wall Japanese restaurant owned by a very nice Japanese owner.
Other pupus and entrees are very good as well.
Temporary they are serving food with plastic containers which is understandable too.

My girlfriend and i were both craving japanese food, and this was the perfect spot. A very laid back place with a diverse menu, fresh fish, and great entrees. Not to mention lovely staff! We ordered quite a few things, and our favorites were the tuna crispy rice, yakiniku, and katsu curry rice! I would certainly suggest coming here!

response:
Edomasa, located at 2710 De La Vina St in Santa Barbara, CA, is a standout sushi bar and Japanese restaurant that offers a harmonious blend of sushi and homey Japanese dishes. The restaurant is known for its authentic and diverse menu, which caters to both rice-only enthusiasts and those who enjoy a mix of sushi and Japanese homey dishes. With a 3.5-star rating and numerous glowing reviews, Edomasa is highly regarded for its exceptional food quality and friendly service.

The restaurant's casual ambiance, which is described as laid-back and inviting, makes it a welcoming spot for both casual dining and groups. It is open from 5:00 PM to 9:30 PM on weekdays and 5:00 PM to 9:30 PM on Saturdays. While the restaurant does not offer reservations or outdoor seating, it is highly recommended for its authentic Japanese experience and the care with which every dish is prepared. The staff is noted for their warmth and welcoming nature, enhancing the overall dining experience.

In addition to its on-site dining, Edomasa also provides takeout services, ensuring that the high-quality food can be enjoyed at home or elsewhere. The restaurant's dedication to both traditional and innovative Japanese cuisine has earned it a reputation as one of the best sushi spots in Santa Barbara, making it a must-visit for anyone looking for a genuine Japanese dining experience. The family-friendly atmosphere and the excellent service contribute to a memorable and enjoyable visit.

review_info.review_text: So I ordered a sandwich from here on Black Friday. There was nothing on the website that stated they are closed and not accepting ordered. So when I walked to south coast they were closed. I checked my email confirmation and it said my sandwich wasn't going to be ready till the Monday. If that's not shady, inconvenient and rude Idk what is. So I made an order again, on Friday but this time I called. I asked to speak with the manager and I told him what had happened. He said they are working on processing the orders but that I should have received the refund already, I told him it wasn't there and then he said  my refund should be in by Wednesday the latest. So I went ahead and ordered and paid for another sandwich. I even tipped them. So Wednesday comes around and nothing. So Friday comes and I call and the manager isn't there, supposedly he was going to be in the next day. I left my name and number and no call back. Monday or Tuesday rolls along and I call back and speak with the manager Blair. He politely says they are working on processing the orders still that there was an issue with the systems. So I wait a few days and he calls me back, doesn't leave a voicemail, we're  playing phone tag at this point and I finally got to speak with him yesterday. He says the owner already processed the orders and that my refund should be there. Well it wasn't. Just like he claimed a few days before. Now why would I go through the trouble of lying and doing all of this? I even asked if they could just give me a free sandwich and drink and call it even. That's the right thing to do. I even told him I'll show you my bank statements, and he agreed to it. I told him, I'll be there after 3pm, I really like coming to this place for my lunch breaks. So I ordered another sandwich over the phone. I get there and the associate screen shots my statements and then tells me he can't give it to me for free. That they need to handle it with the higher up's. I asked he could call his manager and he refused. So I walked out. I'm not supporting a business that steals people's hard earned money. They took $17.26 from me. They deserve or need free donation. They are million dollar company that lacks integrity. The owner should be ashamed of himself and the manager Blair, next  time you call, leave a voice mail like a true professional. That's what managers are suppose to do.
